questions.prompt: Which HTML element represents the root of an HTML document?
questions.explanation: The <html> element is the root element of an HTML document and contains all other elements except the <!DOCTYPE> declaration.

questions.prompt: The <meta charset="UTF-8"> tag should be placed inside the <body> element.
questions.explanation: The <meta charset="UTF-8"> tag should be placed in the <head> section, not the <body>. It defines the character encoding for the document.

questions.prompt: Which attribute is required for the element?
questions.explanation: The src attribute is required for elements as it specifies the path to the image. While alt is highly recommended for accessibility, src is technically required.

questions.prompt: What is the correct HTML for creating a hyperlink?
questions.explanation: The <a> element with the href attribute is used to create hyperlinks in HTML.

questions.prompt: The HTML element used to define the title of a document shown in the browser tab is ___.
questions.explanation: The <title> element, placed in the <head> section, defines the document title shown in the browser tab and search results.

questions.prompt: Which input type provides a date picker in modern browsers?
questions.explanation: The <input type="date"> creates a date picker control in browsers that support it, allowing users to select dates easily.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the "action" attribute in a <form> element?
options: It specifies where to send form data
questions.correctAnswer: It specifies where to send form data
questions.explanation: The action attribute specifies the URL where the form data should be sent when submitted.

questions.prompt: The <label> element can be associated with an input using the "for" attribute that matches the input's "id".
questions.explanation: The for attribute of <label> should match the id of the associated input element, improving accessibility and allowing users to click the label to focus the input.

questions.prompt: Which attribute makes an input field required in HTML5?
questions.explanation: The required attribute is a boolean attribute that prevents form submission if the field is empty.

questions.prompt: To create a dropdown list in HTML, you use the ___ element with nested <option> elements.
questions.explanation: The <select> element creates a dropdown list, containing one or more <option> elements representing the choices.

questions.prompt: Which semantic HTML5 element should be used for a self-contained composition that could be independently distributed?
questions.explanation: <article> represents a self-contained composition intended to be independently distributable or reusable, such as a blog post, news article, or forum post.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between <section> and <div>?
options: <section> is semantic and represents thematic grouping
questions.correctAnswer: <section> is semantic and represents thematic grouping
questions.explanation: <section> is a semantic element representing a thematic grouping of content, while <div> is a generic container with no semantic meaning.

questions.prompt: The <nav> element should only be used for the main navigation block and not for all groups of links.
questions.explanation: The <nav> element should be reserved for major navigation blocks. Not all groups of links need to be in a <nav> element, only sections consisting of major navigation blocks.

questions.prompt: Which element is best for tangentially related content, like a sidebar?
questions.explanation: The <aside> element represents content that is tangentially related to the main content, commonly used for sidebars, pull quotes, or related links.

questions.prompt: The ___ element represents introductory content for its nearest ancestor sectioning content or sectioning root element.
questions.explanation: The <header> element represents introductory content, typically containing headings, logos, navigation, or other introductory information.

questions.prompt: Which CSS property is used to change the text color of an element?
questions.explanation: The color property in CSS is used to set the color of text content.

questions.prompt:
What is the correct syntax for selecting all

elements?
questions.explanation: Element selectors use just the element name without any prefix. Classes use ".", IDs use "#", and "*" is the universal selector.

questions.prompt: In CSS, "padding" adds space outside the element's border.
questions.explanation: Padding adds space inside the element's border, between the content and the border. Margin adds space outside the border.

questions.prompt: Which property is used to change the background color?
questions.explanation: The background-color property sets the background color of an element.

questions.prompt: The CSS box model consists of content, padding, ___, and margin.
questions.explanation: The CSS box model layers are: content (innermost), padding, border, and margin (outermost).

questions.prompt: What does "display: flex" do to an element?
questions.explanation: display: flex makes an element a flex container, enabling flexbox layout for its children (flex items).

questions.prompt: Which flexbox property aligns items along the main axis?
questions.explanation: justify-content aligns flex items along the main axis (horizontal by default), while align-items works on the cross axis.

questions.prompt: CSS Grid is one-dimensional while Flexbox is two-dimensional.
questions.explanation: This is backwards: Flexbox is one-dimensional (row or column), while CSS Grid is two-dimensional (rows and columns simultaneously).

questions.prompt: Which position value removes an element from the document flow?
questions.explanation: Both absolute and fixed remove elements from the document flow, but absolute is the most common answer. Fixed also removes from flow but is positioned relative to viewport.

questions.prompt: The CSS property ___ is used to control the stacking order of overlapping elements.
questions.explanation: z-index controls the stack order of positioned elements (elements with position other than static). Higher values appear in front.

questions.prompt: What is the specificity order from lowest to highest?
questions.explanation: CSS specificity from lowest to highest: element selectors (1), class selectors (10), ID selectors (100), inline styles (1000).

questions.prompt: Given CSS Grid: grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr); What does "1fr" represent?
questions.explanation: The "fr" unit represents a fraction of the available space in the grid container. "1fr" means one fractional unit of the remaining space.

questions.prompt: The :nth-child(2n) selector targets every even child element.
questions.explanation: :nth-child(2n) or :nth-child(even) selects every even-numbered child (2nd, 4th, 6th, etc.).

questions.prompt: What is the difference between "em" and "rem" units?
options: em is relative to parent, rem to root element
rem is relative to parent, em to root element
em is pixels, rem is percentages
questions.correctAnswer: em is relative to parent, rem to root element
questions.explanation: em units are relative to the font-size of the parent element, while rem (root em) units are relative to the root element (<html>) font-size.

questions.prompt: The CSS property ___ can be used to create a grid container with implicit row sizing.
questions.explanation: grid-auto-rows specifies the size of implicitly-created grid rows (rows not explicitly defined with grid-template-rows).

questions.prompt: Which keyword is used to declare a block-scoped variable in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Both let and const create block-scoped variables. The difference is that const creates a constant reference that cannot be reassigned.

questions.prompt: In JavaScript, "5" + 3 results in 53.
questions.explanation: When using the + operator with a string and a number, JavaScript coerces the number to a string and concatenates them, resulting in "53".

questions.prompt: What is the correct way to declare a function in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Functions are declared using the "function" keyword followed by the function name and parentheses.

questions.prompt: Which method adds an element to the end of an array?
questions.explanation: push() adds one or more elements to the end of an array. pop() removes from end, shift() removes from beginning, unshift() adds to beginning.

questions.prompt: To access a property "name" of an object "person", you can use person.___ or person["name"].
questions.explanation: Object properties can be accessed using dot notation (person.name) or bracket notation (person["name"]).

questions.prompt: What does [...arr1, ...arr2] do in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The spread operator (...) expands array elements. [...arr1, ...arr2] creates a new array combining all elements from both arrays.

questions.prompt: What is array destructuring in ES6?
questions.explanation: Array destructuring allows unpacking values from arrays into distinct variables: const [a, b] = [1, 2].

questions.prompt: Arrow functions have their own "this" binding.
questions.explanation: Arrow functions do not have their own "this" binding. They inherit "this" from the enclosing lexical scope.

questions.prompt: What does the map() method do?
options: Creates a new array by transforming each element
questions.correctAnswer: Creates a new array by transforming each element
questions.explanation: map() creates a new array by calling a function on every element of the original array and using the return values.

questions.prompt: The ___ method returns the first element in an array that satisfies a testing function.
questions.explanation: The find() method returns the first element that satisfies the provided testing function. If no element satisfies it, undefined is returned.

questions.prompt: What is the output of: const obj = {a: 1}; const {a: b} = obj; console.log(b);
questions.explanation: This is destructuring with renaming. {a: b} extracts the property "a" from obj and assigns it to a new variable "b", so b equals 1.

questions.prompt: What is a closure in JavaScript?
options: A function with access to outer scope variables
questions.correctAnswer: A function with access to outer scope variables
questions.explanation: A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer (enclosing) lexical scope, even after the outer function has returned.

questions.prompt: The reduce() method can be used to sum all numbers in an array.
questions.explanation: reduce() executes a reducer function on each array element, resulting in a single output value. It's commonly used for summing: arr.reduce((sum, num) => sum + num, 0).

questions.prompt: What is the difference between == and === in JavaScript?
options: == checks value, === checks value and type
questions.correctAnswer: == checks value, === checks value and type
questions.explanation: == performs type coercion before comparison, while === (strict equality) checks both value and type without coercion.

questions.prompt: The ___ keyword is used to define a class in ES6 JavaScript.
questions.explanation: ES6 introduced the class keyword for defining classes, providing syntactic sugar over JavaScript's prototype-based inheritance.

questions.prompt: Which method selects an element by its ID?
questions.explanation: document.getElementById() selects a single element by its ID attribute. It returns the element or null if not found.

questions.prompt: querySelector() returns all matching elements.
questions.explanation: querySelector() returns only the first element that matches the selector. Use querySelectorAll() to get all matching elements.

questions.prompt: How do you change the text content of an element?
questions.explanation: The textContent property sets or returns the text content of an element and its descendants.

questions.prompt: Which property is used to change the HTML content of an element?
questions.explanation: innerHTML gets or sets the HTML markup contained within an element. Use with caution as it can introduce XSS vulnerabilities.

questions.prompt: To add a CSS class to an element, use element.classList.___("className").
questions.explanation: The classList.add() method adds one or more class names to an element. Use classList.remove() to remove classes.

questions.prompt: What is event delegation?
options: Attaching events to parent instead of children
questions.correctAnswer: Attaching events to parent instead of children
questions.explanation: Event delegation attaches an event listener to a parent element to handle events from its children, leveraging event bubbling for efficiency.

questions.prompt: The addEventListener() method can attach multiple handlers to the same event.
questions.explanation: addEventListener() allows multiple event handlers for the same event on an element, unlike onclick which only allows one handler.

questions.prompt: What does event.preventDefault() do?
questions.explanation: preventDefault() prevents the default action of an event (e.g., preventing form submission or link navigation).

questions.prompt: What does event.stopPropagation() do?
questions.explanation: stopPropagation() prevents the event from bubbling up to parent elements in the DOM tree.

questions.prompt: To create a new HTML element in JavaScript, use document.___("tagName").
questions.explanation: document.createElement() creates a new element node with the specified tag name. It must be appended to the DOM to be visible.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between event.target and event.currentTarget?
options: target is the element that triggered, currentTarget is where listener is attached
target is for bubbling, currentTarget for capturing
questions.correctAnswer: target is the element that triggered, currentTarget is where listener is attached
questions.explanation: event.target is the element that actually triggered the event, while event.currentTarget is the element to which the event listener is attached.

questions.prompt: The capturing phase occurs before the bubbling phase in event propagation.
questions.explanation: Event propagation has three phases: capturing (top-down), target, and bubbling (bottom-up). Capturing occurs first.

questions.prompt: Which method removes an element from the DOM?
questions.explanation: The remove() method removes the element from the DOM. Alternatively, you can use parentNode.removeChild(element).

questions.prompt: What does element.getAttribute("href") return if the attribute doesn't exist?
questions.explanation: getAttribute() returns null if the specified attribute does not exist on the element.

questions.prompt: The ___ method inserts an element as the last child of a parent element.
questions.explanation: appendChild() adds a node as the last child of a parent node. For more flexibility, use append() which can also add text and multiple nodes.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the viewport meta tag?
options: To control page dimensions on mobile
questions.correctAnswer: To control page dimensions on mobile
questions.explanation: The viewport meta tag controls how the page is displayed on mobile devices, typically set to <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">.

questions.prompt: Media queries allow you to apply CSS styles based on device characteristics.
questions.explanation: Media queries enable responsive design by applying different CSS rules based on device characteristics like screen width, height, orientation, and resolution.

questions.prompt: Which CSS unit is relative to the viewport width?
questions.explanation: vw (viewport width) is a relative unit where 1vw equals 1% of the viewport width. Similarly, vh represents viewport height.

questions.prompt: What does "mobile-first" design mean?
options: Start with mobile styles, then add desktop
questions.correctAnswer: Start with mobile styles, then add desktop
questions.explanation: Mobile-first design means writing CSS for mobile devices first, then using media queries to add styles for larger screens.

questions.prompt: A common breakpoint for tablets in responsive design is around ___ pixels.
questions.explanation: Common breakpoints are: mobile (~320-480px), tablet (~768px), desktop (~1024px), and large desktop (~1200px+). 768px is the standard tablet breakpoint.

questions.prompt: What does @media (min-width: 768px) mean?
questions.explanation: min-width: 768px means the styles apply when the viewport is 768px or wider. This is used in mobile-first design.

questions.prompt: Which attribute makes images responsive?
questions.explanation: Setting max-width: 100% and height: auto makes images responsive, allowing them to scale down but not exceed their original size.

questions.prompt: ARIA labels improve accessibility for screen readers.
questions.explanation: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes like aria-label provide additional context for screen readers, improving accessibility.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the "alt" attribute in images?
questions.explanation: The alt attribute provides alternative text for images, crucial for accessibility and displayed when images fail to load.

questions.prompt: The CSS property ___ can hide elements visually while keeping them accessible to screen readers.
questions.explanation: Using position: absolute with clip or clip-path hides elements visually while keeping them in the DOM for screen readers. Also acceptable: "position" or "visibility" with specific techniques.

questions.prompt: What does the "prefers-reduced-motion" media query detect?
questions.explanation: prefers-reduced-motion detects if the user has requested minimal motion in their system settings, important for accessibility and motion sensitivity.

questions.prompt: Using rem units instead of px improves accessibility for users who change their browser's default font size.
questions.explanation: rem units are relative to the root font size, so they scale with user preferences. This respects users who increase font size for better readability.

questions.prompt: What does the CSS clamp(1rem, 2vw, 2rem) do?
options: Sets responsive value between min and max
questions.correctAnswer: Sets responsive value between min and max
questions.explanation: clamp(min, preferred, max) sets a value that grows/shrinks with the preferred value (2vw) but never goes below min (1rem) or above max (2rem).

questions.prompt: What is the recommended minimum contrast ratio for normal text (WCAG AA)?
questions.explanation: WCAG 2.0 level AA requires a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text (18pt+ or 14pt+ bold).

questions.prompt: The ___ element provides a container for multiple image sources, enabling responsive images.
questions.explanation: The element contains multiple elements for different image sources and an fallback, enabling art direction and responsive images.

questions.prompt: What is a Promise in JavaScript?
options: An object representing eventual completion or failure
questions.correctAnswer: An object representing eventual completion or failure
questions.explanation: A Promise is an object representing the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value.

questions.prompt: Promises can be in one of three states: pending, fulfilled, or rejected.
questions.explanation: A Promise starts in the pending state, then transitions to either fulfilled (resolved successfully) or rejected (failed).

questions.prompt: Which method is used to handle a fulfilled Promise?
questions.explanation: .then() handles fulfilled Promises, .catch() handles rejections, and .finally() runs regardless of the outcome.

questions.prompt: What does the Fetch API return?
questions.explanation: The Fetch API returns a Promise that resolves to the Response object representing the response to the request.

questions.prompt: To handle errors in a Promise chain, use the ___ method.
questions.explanation: The .catch() method handles rejection in a Promise chain, catching errors from any previous .then() in the chain.

questions.prompt: What does the async keyword do to a function?
questions.explanation: The async keyword makes a function return a Promise. The function can use await to pause execution for other Promises.

questions.prompt: The await keyword can only be used inside async functions.
questions.explanation: await can only be used inside async functions (or at the top level of modules in modern JavaScript). It pauses execution until the Promise resolves.

questions.prompt: What does await fetch(url) do?
options: Pauses until fetch completes and returns Response
questions.correctAnswer: Pauses until fetch completes and returns Response
questions.explanation: await pauses the async function execution until the fetch Promise resolves, then returns the Response object.

questions.prompt: How do you parse JSON from a fetch response?
questions.explanation: The response.json() method returns a Promise that resolves with the result of parsing the response body as JSON.

questions.prompt: Promise.___ resolves when all promises in an array are fulfilled.
questions.explanation: Promise.all() takes an array of Promises and returns a single Promise that resolves when all input Promises are fulfilled, or rejects if any rejects.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between Promise.all() and Promise.race()?
options: all waits for all, race resolves with first to settle
race waits for all, all for first
questions.correctAnswer: all waits for all, race resolves with first to settle
questions.explanation: Promise.all() waits for all Promises to fulfill (or one to reject), while Promise.race() resolves/rejects with the first Promise to settle.

questions.prompt: Promise.allSettled() waits for all Promises and never rejects.
questions.explanation: Promise.allSettled() waits for all Promises to settle (fulfill or reject) and always fulfills with an array of results, never rejecting.

questions.prompt: What HTTP method does fetch use by default?
questions.explanation: fetch() uses GET by default. To use other methods, specify the method in the options: fetch(url, { method: "POST" }).

questions.prompt: What is CORS in web development?
options: A security feature restricting cross-origin requests
questions.correctAnswer: A security feature restricting cross-origin requests
questions.explanation: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is a security feature that restricts web pages from making requests to a different domain than the one serving the page.

questions.prompt: To handle errors in async/await, use the ___ statement.
questions.explanation: Use try-catch blocks with async/await to handle errors: try { await promise } catch (error) { /* handle error */ }.

questions.prompt: What is npm?
questions.explanation: npm (Node Package Manager) is the default package manager for Node.js, used to install and manage JavaScript packages and dependencies.

questions.prompt: Webpack is a module bundler that bundles JavaScript files for the browser.
questions.explanation: Webpack is a module bundler that takes modules with dependencies and generates static assets representing those modules, primarily for browser use.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of package.json?
questions.explanation: package.json contains metadata about the project and lists dependencies, scripts, version information, and other configuration.

questions.prompt: Which command installs all dependencies listed in package.json?
questions.explanation: npm install (or npm i) reads package.json and installs all dependencies listed in the dependencies and devDependencies sections.

questions.prompt: The ___ file specifies which files should be ignored by Git.
questions.explanation: .gitignore lists files and directories that Git should ignore, commonly including node_modules, build files, and environment variables.

questions.prompt: What is React?
options: A JavaScript library for building UIs
questions.correctAnswer: A JavaScript library for building UIs
questions.explanation: React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building user interfaces, particularly single-page applications with reusable components.

questions.prompt: Babel is a JavaScript compiler that converts modern JavaScript to older versions for browser compatibility.
questions.explanation: Babel is a JavaScript transpiler that converts modern JavaScript (ES6+) into backwards-compatible versions for older browsers.

questions.prompt: What is the virtual DOM in React?
options: A lightweight copy of the actual DOM
questions.correctAnswer: A lightweight copy of the actual DOM
questions.explanation: The virtual DOM is a lightweight representation of the actual DOM. React uses it to optimize updates by comparing changes and updating only what's necessary.

questions.prompt: What does ESLint do?
options: Analyzes code for problems and style issues
questions.correctAnswer: Analyzes code for problems and style issues
questions.explanation: ESLint is a static code analysis tool that identifies problematic patterns and enforces code style in JavaScript code.

questions.prompt: ___ is a popular testing framework for JavaScript that includes assertion, mocking, and spy capabilities.
questions.explanation: Jest is a JavaScript testing framework developed by Facebook, widely used for testing React applications and other JavaScript code.

questions.prompt: What is Server-Side Rendering (SSR)?
options: Generating HTML on the server before sending to client
questions.correctAnswer: Generating HTML on the server before sending to client
questions.explanation: SSR generates the full HTML for a page on the server in response to navigation, improving initial load time and SEO compared to client-side rendering.

questions.prompt: Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) can work offline and be installed on devices.
questions.explanation: PWAs use service workers and web app manifests to enable offline functionality, push notifications, and installation on devices like native apps.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of a Service Worker?
options: Handle network requests and enable offline functionality
questions.correctAnswer: Handle network requests and enable offline functionality
questions.explanation: Service Workers are scripts that run in the background, intercepting network requests, caching resources, and enabling offline functionality and push notifications.

questions.prompt: What is tree shaking in the context of JavaScript bundling?
questions.explanation: Tree shaking is a dead-code elimination technique that removes unused exports from the final bundle, reducing bundle size.

questions.prompt: The process of breaking down a large JavaScript bundle into smaller chunks loaded on demand is called code ___.
questions.explanation: Code splitting divides your bundle into smaller chunks that can be loaded on demand or in parallel, improving initial load time and performance.
